'''Steven Ruggles''' is Regents Professor of History and Population Studies at the [[University of Minnesota]], and the Director of the [[Minnesota Population Center]].

Ruggles, a [[historical demography|historical demographer]], received his Ph.D in history from the [[University of Pennsylvania]] in 1984.<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite web|author=University of Minnesota |url=https://apps.cla.umn.edu/directory/profiles/ruggl001 |title=Steven Ruggles: College of Liberal Arts: U of M |publisher=Apps.cla.umn.edu |date=2010-06-03 |accessdate=2011-12-23}}</ref> He is best known as the creator of the Integrated Public Use Microdata Series ([[IPUMS]]), the world's largest population database. In 1995, Ruggles was described as the "King of Quant" by [[Wired Magazine]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.wired.com/wired/archive/3.03/ruggles_pr.html |title=The King of Quant |publisher=Wired.com |date= |accessdate=2011-12-23 |first=Hillary |last=Rettig}}</ref> Ruggles has made important contributions to the study of long run demographic changes, focusing especially on changes in the family. His study of the effects of demographic change on family structure <ref>Steven Ruggles, ''Prolonged Connections: The Rise of the Extended Family in Nineteenth Century England and America'' Madison: University of Wisconsin Press. 1987 http://www.hist.umn.edu/~ruggles/Articles/ISBNO-299-11034-6.pdf</ref> won the William J. Goode Book Award from the [[American Sociological Association]] and the Allen Sharlen Memorial Award from the Social Science History Association.<ref name="autogenerated1"/> 
Ruggles's work on migration censoring in family reconstitution <ref>Steven Ruggles, "Migration, Marriage, and Mortality: Correcting Sources of Bias in English Family Reconstitutions," ''[[Population Studies]]'' vol. 46 (1992) pp.  507-522</ref>  led to an extended debate about biases introduced by the "Ruggles Effect." <ref>E.A. Wrigley, “The Effect of Migration on the Estimation of Marriage Age in Family Reconstitution Studies,” ''[[Population Studies]]'' vol. 48 (1994) pp.  81-97; Alice Bee Kasakoff and John W. Adams, “The Effect of migration on Ages at Vital Events: A Critique of Family Reconstitution in Historical Demography” ''European Journal of Population'' 11 (1995), pp. 199-242; B. Desjardins, “Bias in Age at Marriage in Family Reconstitutions: Evidence from French-Canadian data.” ''[[Population Studies]]'' 49 (1995) 165–169; E. Voland and R.I.M. Dunbar, “The Impact of Social Status and Migration on Female Age at Marriage in an Historical Population in North-West Germany.” ''Journal of Biosocial Science'' 29(1997), pp. 355-360; Steven Ruggles “The Limitations of English Family Reconstitution.” ''[[Continuity and Change]]'' 14 (1999) 105-130.</ref> The method Ruggles proposed for correcting censoring bias in family reconstitution estimates of mortality was eventually determined to be more accurate than any of the alternative techniques that have been proposed.<ref>M. A. Jonker and  A. W. van der Vaart, “Correcting Missing-Data Bias in Historical Demography” ''[[Population Studies]]'' vol. 61 (2007) pp.  99-114</ref>

In 2003, Ruggles received the Robert J. Lapham Award from the Population Association of America in recognition of lifetime contributions that blend research with the application of demographic knowledge to policy issues,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.popassoc.org/i4a/pages/index.cfm?pageID=3309 |title=Robert J. Lapham Award - Population Association of America |publisher=Popassoc.org |date= |accessdate=2011-12-23}}</ref> and in 2009 he received the Warren E. Miller Award from the Inter-university Consortium for Political and Social Research for meritorious service to the social sciences.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.icpsr.umich.edu/icpsrweb/content/membership/awards/ruggles.html |title=Warren E. Miller Award |publisher=icpsr.umich.edu |date= |accessdate=2013-01-18}}</ref> He is currently serving as the 2015 President of the [[Population Association of America]], the first historian to hold the position.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Norling|first1=Lisa|authorlink1=Lisa Norling|title=Steve Ruggles to Head the Population Association of America|url=http://cla.umn.edu/history/news-events/news/steve-ruggles-head-population-association-america|website=[[University of Minnesota College of Liberal Arts|College of Liberal Arts]]|publisher=[[University of Minnesota]]|accessdate=May 25, 2015|date=June 22, 2014}}</ref>

In 1994, Ruggles married [[Lisa Norling]], another historian. He currently lives in [[Minneapolis]] with his two children and his wife.
